results.title: The Eternal forest
results.brief_description: Designed to explain the important part played by forests in paper manufacture. Photographed in the Boola-Boola area of Gippsland, Victoria, various operations are shown in which timber, removed for papermaking, is being replaced by seedling pines which will mature for use in future years. The film includes views of the residential area of Traralgon, the manufacturing processes at the Maryvale mill, and also lists various uses of paper products.

results.title: The Eskimo: fight for life
results.creator_credit: Robert Young, Quentin Brown and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An authentic record of the life of the Netsilik Inuit of the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic during their last migratory camp. It shows the old Inuit culture, the communal life of the seal hunters and their families, their complete adaptation to the environment. This film was produced, with commentary from footage brought out of the Arctic by anthropologists. (Award: New York)

results.title: The End of St Petersburg = Konyets Sankt-Peterburga [DVD]
results.brief_description: Originally made to commemorate the tenth year of the overthrow of Czarist Russia, Pudovkin’s film tells the story of a peasant boy who comes to St. Petersburg in search of work and witnesses the October Revolution. Set against the background of the historical events which culminated in the attack on the Winter Palace, the film contains graphic anti-war statements and was so realistically shot, that some interpreted the footage as documentary evidence of real events. Despite numerous crowd scenes, Pudovkin focuses on the struggle of the individual to relay the concerns of a people. Contains striking black and white cinematography, and expressionistic performances from Alexander Chistyakov and Vera Baranovska. Based on the poem, “The Bronze horseman” by Pushkin and the novel “St Petersburg” by Andrev Biely.

results.title: The Emerging eskimo
results.creator_credit: Brayton-Kendall Productions and Centron Educational Films
results.brief_description: Documentary film showing the effect of colonisation on the Eskimo socio-culture. Since the first arrival of the Europeans, the selling potential of Alaskan resources was quickly realised. This caused devastating damage to ecological aspects vital to Eskimo survival. In addition tho this, the film shows how colonial influence has caused ruptures in Eskimo tradition and religion.

results.title: The Eleven Powers
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Larry Gartenstein and Cinetel Productions
results.brief_description: In 1979, the Festival of the Eleven Powers took place on the island of Bali. The festival is called into being every 100 years to mark the closing of the Balinese century and re-establish the balance of the positive and negative forces in the world. Over two million people took part in the sixty days of purification and religious fervour. Script by Bryce Courtenay and narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: The edge of the possible
results.creator_credit: Daryl Dellora, Sue Maslin and Film Art Doco Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Joern Utzon, the Danish architect of the Sydney Opera House lives in Hellebaek, Denmark in a modest house he built himself. He is 80 years old and in his distinguished career he has recieved every major archticetural award. But in February 1966, it was a very differet story. In that month his nine years work on the Opera House came to an end. This beautifully photographed films charts the triumphant, exhilarating and then tragic course of the design and construction of the Sydney Opera House. For the first time in 25 years Joern Utzon appears in a lengthy interview speaking in English.
